The  Baipaza  landslide  in  southern  Tajikistan  blocked  the  Vakhsh 
River following an earthquake on 3 March 2002. This earthquake 
had  its  epicenter  in  neighboring  Afghanistan  with  a  recorded 
magnitude  of  7.4  on  the  Richter  scale.  Initially,  the  landslide 
blocked  the  narrow  waterway  of  the  Vakhsh  River  approximately 
5 km downstream of the Baipaza Hydro Power Station (BHPS) in 
Khatlon Region, southern Tajikistan. As a consequence, the water 
level rose by about 7 meters (m), threatening to flood the BHPS. 
Also,  generation  of  power  and  supply  of  water  for  irrigation  was 
disrupted.  The  Government  took  the  immediate  measure  of 
blasting the landslide materials from the river to avoid flooding the 
BHPS.  Since  the  first  movement  of  3  March,  the  landslide  has 
been  moving  at  speeds  varying  between  a  few  millimeters  to 
1  centimeter  a  day.  There  is  an  imminent  danger  that  sudden 
movement  of  the  landslide  will  completely  block  the  river  thus 
submerging the BHPS. The Project aims to restore reliable water 
flows  and  initiate  disaster  prevention  measures  by  (i)  minimizing 
the  occurrence  and  the  magnitude  of  the  landslide,  (ii)  mitigating 
its impact on the flow of the Vaskhsh River and its blockage, and 
(iii) studying a long-term solution.  
 
Maintaining  reliable  water  flows  in  the  Vakhsh  River  is  vital  for 
Tajikistan  and  the  downstream  countries  of  Uzbekistan  and 
Turkmenistan.  Any  blockage  of  the  Vakhsh  River  would  disrupt 
the  generation  of  the  Vakhsh  River  cascade  comprising  five 
hydropower  stations  totaling  3,858  megawatts  (MW)  of  installed 
generation  or  90%  of  total  generation  capacity  of  the  country. 
In  the  worst  case,  90%  of  the  electricity  generating  capacity  of 
Tajikistan  could  be  at  risk.  In  addition,  blockage  of  the  Vakhsh 
River  would  endanger  the  water  supply  to  downstream  users  for 
agriculture, industry, and drinking water. This would affect people 
in  the  Khatlon  Region,  and  would  disrupt  water  supply  to 
Uzbekistan  and  Turkmenistan.  Further,  a  sudden  breach  of  any 
landslide  dam  would  pose  a  threat  to  downstream  communities, 
installations, and infrastructure.

2. 
Maintaining  reliable  water  flows  in  the  Vakhsh  River  is  vital  for  Tajikistan  and  the 
downstream  countries  of  Uzbekistan  and  Turkmenistan.  Any  blockage  of  the  Vakhsh  River 
would disrupt the generation of the Vakhsh River cascade comprising five hydropower stations 
totaling 3,858 megawatts (MW) of installed generation or 90% of total generation capacity of the 
country.  In  the  worst  case,  90%  of  the  electricity  generating  capacity  of  Tajikistan  could  be  at 
risk. In addition, blockage of the Vakhsh River would endanger the water supply to downstream 
users  for  agriculture,  industry,  and  drinking  water.    This  would  affect  people  in  the  Khatlon 
Region, and would disrupt water supply to Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. A sudden breach of 
any  landslide  dam  would  pose  a  threat  to  downstream  communities,  installations,  and 
infrastructure. 
 
3. 
Hydropower is the major source of energy in Tajikistan and plays an important role in the 
national economy. It accounts for well over 90% of the energy supply. Tajikistan's power system 
comprises  three  separate  power  grids,  the  north,  south  and  the  Gorno-Badakhshan  systems, 
which  are  operated  by  Barki  Tajik.  The  installed  generation  capacity  totals  4,354  megawatts 
(MW), including 4,000 MW of hydropower capacity. Out of this, the Cascade River plants of the 
Vakhsh  River  represent  3,858  MW.  In  summer  time,  Tajikistan  has  on  average  an  energy 
surplus of about 4,200 gigawatts (GWh), which is exported mainly to Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan 
and Uzbekistan. In wintertime, Tajikistan imports electricity from Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan 
to meet the energy demand mainly for heating. All major hydropower plants are on the Vakhsh 
River.  Nurek  Hydropower  station  (NHPS)  with  3,000  MW  of  installed  capacity  is  the  largest  in 
Central  Asia  and  generates  electricity  throughout  the  year.  It  was  constructed  in  stages  from 
1962 to 1979, and regulates the Vakhsh River flow, on a seasonal basis, for irrigation needs of 
the Amu Darya basin countries (Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan) during the growing season (May 
to  July).  Baipaza  Hydro  Power  Station  (BPHS),  located  35  kilometers  (km)  downstream  of 
NHPS, regulates the river flow on a daily basis and has a capacity of 600 MW. BHPS has been 
in operation since 1985. The Baipaza reservoir is used for water supply and irrigation purposes 
of nine regions with irrigated area of around 173,000 ha.1 This region covers most of the area 
south  of  Dushanbe,  which  has  a  population  of  more  than  2  million  and  has  been  identified  by 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) as a poor region under the ongoing power rehabilitation project 
loan.2

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities

Analysis.  On  3  March  2002  at  4:10  pm,  Tajikistan  experienced  an  earthquake  of 
magnitude  7.4  on  the  Richter  scale  and  with  its  epicenter  in  Afghanistan.  The  earthquake 
triggered a mass of earth and rocks to slide into the Vakhsh River 5 km downstream of BHPS 
on the Vakhsh River in Khatlon Region. The first landslide partly blocked the narrow waterway 
of  the  Vakhsh  River,  causing  the  water  level  at  the  landslide  to  rise  by  7  meters  (m),  and 
threatening to flood upstream BHPS. The heavy rains that followed the landslide in early March 
worsened  this.  Flows  to  the  Pravaya-Vetka  main  canal  assisted  under  an  ADB  emergency 
loan,3 could be affected by such an event. This canal is fed through a tunnel that takes water in 
from the reservoir of BHPS and provides irrigation supplies to 26,000 ha and provides potable 
water  to  220,000  people  in  three  districts.  Since  the  first  movement  on  3  March  2002,  the 
landslide has been moving at speeds varying from a few millimeters to 1 centimeter per day. A 
more detailed description of the landslide is given in Appendix 1. 
 
5. 
To allow the river channel to be cleared sufficiently to enable the free flow of water, the 
BHPS had to be stopped during the day and operated only partially during the night. Explosives 
were used to remove the natural dam, and from 12 April to 22 April the BHPS was operated at 
half  capacity,  releasing  water  only  for  the  minimum  of  irrigation  requirements  downstream.  A 
further  cessation  of  operation  will  be  necessary  to  allow  additional  widening  of  the  riverbed  at 
the landslide location, in order to decrease the water level at the BHPS by a further 2 m.  
 
6. 
The immediate and direct impact of future river blockages will be the disruption of power 
generation  in  Tajikistan  and  water  supply  for  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and  Uzbekistan, 
including  for  irrigation  of  around  173,000  ha.  NHPS,  as  the  largest  hydropower  station  of  the 
Central  Asian  Electric  System,  is  a  significant  contributor  to  the  region's  load-frequency 
regulation.  Should  the  Vakhsh  River  become  blocked,  the  NHPS  will  have  to  cease  operation 
temporarily,  and  the  stability  of  the  whole  Central  Asian  System  may  suffer.  In  addition,  the 
BHPS would be submerged and severely damaged by flooding. 
 
7. 
The indirect impact will be the stoppage of aluminum production, which is highly energy 
dependent. Tajik Aluminum Smelter (TADAZ), the government-owned aluminum smelter, is one 
of  the  largest  industrial  users  of  electricity  and  had  a  demand  of  about  600  MW  in  2002.  The 
hydropower  plant  of  Nurek  directly  supplies  the  TADAZ  factory.  This  factory,  with  a  capacity 
estimated  at  390,000  tons  per  year,  exports  almost  the  entire  aluminum  production, 
predominantly  to  the  Netherlands  (49%),  Turkey  (19%),  Belgium  (13%),  and  Iran  (6%).  A 
blocking  of  the  Vakhsh  River  would  therefore  drastically  reduce  foreign  currency  revenues  for 
Tajikistan. 
 
8. 
Finally, if a river blockage were to occur and could not be removed quickly, then, in the 
worst  case  outcome,  the  resultant  dam  could  eventually  breach  catastrophically,  resulting  in 
downstream flooding and damage to livelihoods, power generation, and water supply.

THE BAIPAZA LANDSLIDE 
 
 
 

On 3 March 2002, an earthquake triggered a landslide 5 kilometers (km) downstream of 
1. 
the  Baipaza  Hydro  Power  Station  (BHPS).  This  was  the  second  earthquake  (the  first  was  in 
1992) at this location since the commissioning of the BHPS in 1986, although the first recorded 
failure  took  place  in  1968,  before  the  BHPS  was  constructed.  In  March  1968  the  landslide 
comprised 25–30 million cubic meters (m3) of material and the river was blocked for 2 weeks to 
an  elevation  of  600  meters  (m)  upstream  of  the  landslide  dam  (the  current  water  level  is 
approximately 565–570 m and the elevation of the turbine hall at the BHPS is 581.5 m). In May 
1992, the level of the water upstream of the landslide rose to 580 m. The March 2002 landslide 
resulted in a 5 m high natural dam causing a water level rise to 572 m at the landslide and an 
increase in water level of 7–8 m at the BHPS.  
 
2. 
The landslide is part of an area of ancient (probably immediately post-glacial) deep-seated 
failure involving the entire valley side. The Baipaza landslide is approximately 1,800 m in length 
and  800  m  wide  at  its  widest  part,  alongside  the  River  Vakhsh.  The  landslide  has  a  shape  and 
mechanism of movement similar to an egg timer. The upper part is a wide source area of failing 
ground  whereby  large  masses  of  slope  are  detached  progressively.  These  masses  rapidly  find 
their way through the narrow throat of the landslide and are deposited onto a large colluvial mass 
of material that forms the entire lower slope adjacent to the river. The depth of this mass is about 
30–40  m.  Slippage  is  continuing  due  to  loading  from  failing  materials  and  the  build  up  of 
groundwater during the wet season. Due to the control of flow in the river by the upstream power 
stations (Baipaza and Nurek), river scour of the toe of the slope is unlikely to be as severe as it 
might otherwise have been prior to construction of the installations.  
 
3. 
The  total  volume  of  the  landslide  is  unknown,  but  is  estimated  by  Barki  Tajik  to  be  
5 million to 25 million m3. The Mission’s observations suggest that the landslide might be of the 
order of 7 million to10 million m3. The current speed of landslide movement is estimated to be in 
the  range  of  0.7  to  1.0  centimeter  (cm)  per  day,  which  is  a  dry  season  rate,  and  rates  of 
movement in the forthcoming wet season are anticipated to be much higher. 
 
4. 
It  is  impossible  to  say  when  and  to  what  extent  the  next  failure  will  occur.  Slope 
movement will be governed significantly by the rainfall pattern and the timing and magnitude of 
seismic  activity.  The  failure  of  approximately  350,000  m3  is  imminent  in  the  mudslide  at  the 
northern  end  of  the  landslide  adjacent  to  the  river.  If  only  a  third  of  this  material  reaches  the 
waterway, it could block the river to a similar depth as the slide in 1968 (30 m). Such a failure 
could also activate a much larger unstable area immediately upslope with a volume approaching 
1 million m3 or more. All of this material is not likely to be deposited in the river instantaneously. 
If  the  rainfall  conditions  over  the  next  few  years  remain  low  to  moderate,  and  the  area  is  not 
affected by any significant seismic or blasting activity, then slope failures during the short term 
could  be  relatively  small,  especially  if  the  proposed  works  at  the  top  of  the  slide  are 
implemented  rapidly  and  effectively.  However,  the  future  behavior  of  the  landslide,  even  over  
1–3 years cannot be predicted with any certainty, and a large failure could occur. Therefore, the 
monitoring of movements on the slide should be expanded and extended to record the details of 
movements  during  the  forthcoming  and  following  wet  seasons  and  a  rain  gauge  should  be 
established this dry season at the BHPS to compare movements against recorded rainfall.

The Baipaza Landslide is approximately 60 kilometers (km) southeast of Dushanbe the

estimated  650,000  people  depend  partly  or  fully  on  the  Vakhsh  River  for  water  supply.  The

The Project concerns the restoration of reliable water flow of the Vaskhsh River, which is used for power
